title: Wandering pirate
data:
**Wandering pirates** are monsters that appear in [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and the [Pirate patch](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate"). When carrying the Pirate [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"), [the Treasury of Proteus](/wiki/The_Treasury_of_Proteus "The Treasury of Proteus"), wandering pirates will occasionally appear and fight the player for the Treasury. These monsters are otherwise not randomly generated in the game, although skeletal pirates will randomly appear in the [Pirate quest](/wiki/Pirate_quest "Pirate quest"), and several skeletal pirates and damned pirates are guaranteed to appear on certain levels of the quest.

In bones levels, dead [Pirates](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate") may return as skeletal pirates.

These monsters are also included in [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), along with other features of the Pirate role.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"Are wandering pirate species part of random monster generation in SlashTHEM?"*

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Skeletal pirate](#Skeletal_pirate)
- [3 Damned pirate](#Damned_pirate)
- [4 Githyanki pirate](#Githyanki_pirate)
  - [4.1 Origin](#Origin)
- [5 References](#References)

## Generation

Wandering pirate generation uses a mechanism separate from ordinary monster generation. While the player [has the Treasury in open inventory](/wiki/The_Treasury_of_Proteus#King_of_the_Hill "The Treasury of Proteus"), there will be a 20% chance that whenever a new monster is randomly generated, it will be replaced with one or more wandering pirates. Wandering pirates will always be of a type appropriate for the theme of that part of the dungeon: damned pirates in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"), githyanki pirates in the [end game](/wiki/End_game "End game"), skeletal pirates elsewhere.

The difficulty, attack strength, and armor quality of the type of wandering pirate the player encounters increase with the stage of the game where they appear, but otherwise they are significantly weaker than the monsters that could have been generated otherwise, especially because of their lack of special abilities or attacks. Although they all implicitly want the Treasury, none of the three types is designated as [covetous](/wiki/Covetous "Covetous"), so they can't teleport to the Pirate carrying the artifact, and none of the monsters have a [thieving](/wiki/Theft_\(attack\) "Theft (attack)") attack. They will also fight with other monsters and one another.

By preventing more difficult monsters from being generated, this effect of carrying the Treasury may actually be more helpful than harmful to the player. Also, in dNetHack they provide a way to acquire more [bullets](/wiki/Bullet "Bullet") for the Pirate's starting [flintlock](/wiki/Flintlock "Flintlock"), as anything [firearms](/wiki/Firearms "Firearms")-related is otherwise incredibly rare in this variant.

One of the four possible variants of [The Sea](/wiki/The_Sea_\(dNetHack\) "The Sea (dNetHack)") in dNetHack also features skeletal pirates, with more spawning over time. This is the only way non-Pirate players can naturally (apart from [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") and [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish")) encounter them.

| A skeletal pirate:* can [survive underwater](/wiki/Amphibious "Amphibious").
* [does not breathe](/wiki/Breathless "Breathless").
* is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless").
* has [a head, a couple of arms, and a torso](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid").
* [does not eat](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"). (\*)
* is [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead").
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").
* wanders randomly.
* is [nasty](/wiki/M2_NASTY "M2 NASTY").
* is [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong").
* can pick up weapons and food.
* has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").
* normally appears in small [groups](/wiki/Group "Group").
* [never leaves a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").
* resists death magic.
* cannot be [tamed](/wiki/Scroll_of_taming "Scroll of taming").
* does not naturally [regenerate](/wiki/Regenerate "Regenerate") HP. |                                                                                                                                                |

**Skeletal pirates** first appear during the [Pirate quest](/wiki/Pirate_quest "Pirate quest"). In addition to making up about 55% of all hostile monsters [randomly generated](/wiki/Quest#Monsters "Quest") in the quest, several are guaranteed to appear on each level of the quest. They will continue to appear as wandering pirates after the player leaves the quest.

Skeletal pirates [are generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a [rusty](/wiki/Rusty "Rusty") cutlass ([scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar")) or [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife") and a [rotted](/wiki/Rotted "Rotted") [leather jacket](/wiki/Leather_jacket "Leather jacket") or pair of [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots"). In dNetHack they also get some rusty [bullets](/wiki/Bullet "Bullet") and either a rusty [flintlock](/wiki/Flintlock "Flintlock") or another knife.

**Damned pirates** appear as wandering pirates while the player is traveling through [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") with the Treasury. In addition, a few are guaranteed to appear on the lower levels of the quest.

Damned pirates are generated with a [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") cutlass and a rotted and cursed [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor"). In dNetHack they also get some [bullets](/wiki/Bullet "Bullet") and a cursed [flintlock](/wiki/Flintlock "Flintlock").

* wanders randomly.
* is [nasty](/wiki/M2_NASTY "M2 NASTY").

* can pick up weapons and food.

**Githyanki pirates** begin to appear as wandering pirates once the player reaches the [Elemental Planes](/wiki/Elemental_Planes "Elemental Planes") and [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane").

Githyanki pirates are generated with a [two-handed sword](/wiki/Two-handed_sword "Two-handed sword"), [bronze plate mail](/wiki/Bronze_plate_mail "Bronze plate mail"), [leather gloves](/wiki/Leather_gloves "Leather gloves"), and [high boots](/wiki/High_boots "High boots").

### Origin

Githyanki are humanoids from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*. Bred from human slaves by the illithids ([mind flayers](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer")), they later revolted and established their own society on the Astral Plane.

## References

Reference: [Chris's Pirate Patch](https://github.com/Chris-plus-alphanumericgibberish/NetHack/compare/master...Chris_s_Pirate_Patch.diff)
html:
Wandering pirate

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Wandering pirates are monsters that appear in dNetHack and the Pirate patch. When carrying the Pirate quest artifact, the Treasury of Proteus, wandering pirates will occasionally appear and fight the player for the Treasury. These monsters are otherwise not randomly generated in the game, although skeletal pirates will randomly appear in the Pirate quest, and several skeletal pirates and damned pirates are guaranteed to appear on certain levels of the quest.

In bones levels, dead Pirates may return as skeletal pirates.

These monsters are also included in SlashTHEM, along with other features of the Pirate role.

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"Are wandering pirate species part of random monster generation in SlashTHEM?"

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Skeletal pirate
  • 3 Damned pirate
  • 4 Githyanki pirate
    • 4.1 Origin
  • 5 References

Generation

Wandering pirate generation uses a mechanism separate from ordinary monster generation. While the player has the Treasury in open inventory, there will be a 20% chance that whenever a new monster is randomly generated, it will be replaced with one or more wandering pirates. Wandering pirates will always be of a type appropriate for the theme of that part of the dungeon: damned pirates in Gehennom, githyanki pirates in the end game, skeletal pirates elsewhere.

The difficulty, attack strength, and armor quality of the type of wandering pirate the player encounters increase with the stage of the game where they appear, but otherwise they are significantly weaker than the monsters that could have been generated otherwise, especially because of their lack of special abilities or attacks. Although they all implicitly want the Treasury, none of the three types is designated as covetous, so they can't teleport to the Pirate carrying the artifact, and none of the monsters have a thieving attack. They will also fight with other monsters and one another.

By preventing more difficult monsters from being generated, this effect of carrying the Treasury may actually be more helpful than harmful to the player. Also, in dNetHack they provide a way to acquire more bullets for the Pirate's starting flintlock, as anything firearms-related is otherwise incredibly rare in this variant.

One of the four possible variants of The Sea in dNetHack also features skeletal pirates, with more spawning over time. This is the only way non-Pirate players can naturally (apart from bones and wishing) encounter them.

Skeletal pirate

Z skeletal pirate
Difficulty 7
Attacks Weapon 1d6 physical
Z skeletal pirate
Difficulty 7
Attacks

Weapon 1d6 physical

Base level 5
Base experience 96
Speed 8
Base AC 4
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 300
Nutritional value 5
Size medium
Resistances cold, sleep, poison, petrification

A skeletal pirate:

  • can survive underwater.
  • does not breathe.
  • is mindless.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is undead.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • wanders randomly.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • normally appears in small groups.
  • never leaves a corpse.
  • resists death magic.
  • cannot be tamed.
  • does not naturally regenerate HP.

Skeletal pirates first appear during the Pirate quest. In addition to making up about 55% of all hostile monsters randomly generated in the quest, several are guaranteed to appear on each level of the quest. They will continue to appear as wandering pirates after the player leaves the quest.

Skeletal pirates are generated with a rusty cutlass (scimitar) or knife and a rotted leather jacket or pair of high boots. In dNetHack they also get some rusty bullets and either a rusty flintlock or another knife.

Genocidable No
Weight 300
Nutritional value 5
Size medium
Resistances fire, sleep, poison, petrification

A damned pirate:

  • can survive underwater.
  • does not breathe.
  • is mindless.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is a demon.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • wanders randomly.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • normally appears in small groups.
  • never leaves a corpse.
  • resists death magic.
  • cannot be tamed.

Damned pirates appear as wandering pirates while the player is traveling through Gehennom with the Treasury. In addition, a few are guaranteed to appear on the lower levels of the quest.

Damned pirates are generated with a cursed cutlass and a rotted and cursed leather armor. In dNetHack they also get some bullets and a cursed flintlock.

Githyanki pirate

h githyanki pirate

Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable No
Weight 300
Nutritional value 5
Size medium
Resistances sleep, shock, poison, petrification
Resistances conveyed sleep

A githyanki pirate:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • wanders randomly.
  • is nasty.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • has infravision.
  • normally appears in small groups.
  • cannot be tamed.

Githyanki pirates begin to appear as wandering pirates once the player reaches the Elemental Planes and Astral Plane.

Githyanki pirates are generated with a two-handed sword, bronze plate mail, leather gloves, and high boots.

Origin

Githyanki are humanoids from Dungeons & Dragons. Bred from human slaves by the illithids (mind flayers), they later revolted and established their own society on the Astral Plane.

References

Reference: Chris's Pirate Patch

rawPage:
'''Wandering pirates''' are monsters that appear in [[dNetHack]] and the [[Pirate|Pirate patch]]. When carrying the Pirate [[quest artifact]], [[the Treasury of Proteus]], wandering pirates will occasionally appear and fight the player for the Treasury. These monsters are otherwise not randomly generated in the game, although skeletal pirates will randomly appear in the [[Pirate quest]], and several skeletal pirates and damned pirates are guaranteed to appear on certain levels of the quest. 

In bones levels, dead [[Pirate]]s may return as skeletal pirates.

These monsters are also included in [[SlashTHEM]], along with other features of the Pirate role.
{{todo|Are wandering pirate species part of random monster generation in SlashTHEM?}}

==Generation==
Wandering pirate generation uses a mechanism separate from ordinary monster generation. While the player [[The Treasury of Proteus#King of the Hill|has the Treasury in open inventory]], there will be a 20% chance that whenever a new monster is randomly generated, it will be replaced with one or more wandering pirates. Wandering pirates will always be of a type appropriate for the theme of that part of the dungeon: damned pirates in [[Gehennom]], githyanki pirates in the [[end game]], skeletal pirates elsewhere.

The difficulty, attack strength, and armor quality of the type of wandering pirate the player encounters increase with the stage of the game where they appear, but otherwise they are significantly weaker than the monsters that could have been generated otherwise, especially because of their lack of special abilities or attacks. Although they all implicitly want the Treasury, none of the three types is designated as [[covetous]], so they can't teleport to the Pirate carrying the artifact, and none of the monsters have a [[Theft (attack)|thieving]] attack. They will also fight with other monsters and one another.

By preventing more difficult monsters from being generated, this effect of carrying the Treasury may actually be more helpful than harmful to the player.  Also, in dNetHack they provide a way to acquire more [[bullet]]s for the Pirate's starting [[flintlock]], as anything [[firearms]]-related is otherwise incredibly rare in this variant.

One of the four possible variants of [[The Sea (dNetHack)|The Sea]] in dNetHack also features skeletal pirates, with more spawning over time.  This is the only way non-Pirate players can naturally (apart from [[bones]] and [[wish]]ing) encounter them.

'''Skeletal pirates''' first appear during the [[Pirate quest]]. In addition to making up about 55% of all hostile monsters [[Quest#Monsters|randomly generated]] in the quest, several are guaranteed to appear on each level of the quest. They will continue to appear as wandering pirates after the player leaves the quest.

Skeletal pirates [[Monster starting inventory|are generated with]] a [[rusty]] cutlass ([[scimitar]]) or [[knife]] and a [[rotted]] [[leather jacket]] or pair of [[high boots]].  In dNetHack they also get some rusty [[bullet]]s and either a rusty [[flintlock]] or another knife.
{{clear}}

'''Damned pirates''' appear as wandering pirates while the player is traveling through [[Gehennom]] with the Treasury. In addition, a few are guaranteed to appear on the lower levels of the quest. 

Damned pirates are generated with a [[cursed]] cutlass and a rotted and cursed [[leather armor]].  In dNetHack they also get some [[bullet]]s and a cursed [[flintlock]].
{{clear}}

'''Githyanki pirates''' begin to appear as wandering pirates once the player reaches the [[Elemental Planes]] and [[Astral Plane]]. 

Githyanki pirates are generated with a [[two-handed sword]], [[bronze plate mail]], [[leather gloves]], and [[high boots]].

===Origin===
Githyanki are humanoids from ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]''. Bred from human slaves by the illithids ([[mind flayer]]s), they later revolted and established their own society on the Astral Plane.
{{clear}}
